column1: I am 18+ and consent to take part. I understand anomymised data will be published openly
column2: How often do you use digital or AI-powered tools (e.g., ChatGPT, Copilot, Gemini, AI-enhanced search) in your daily life?
column3: On average, how many hours do you spend online each day? (self-estimate)
column4: What do you use AI for most often? (Select all that apply)
column5: In general, how confident do you feel using AI tools?
column6: AI providing health or wellbeing advice
column7: AI making recommendations about money or finance
column9: AI interacting with children or young people
column10: AI generating information that might be inaccurate
column11: AI forming opinions about someone based on personal data
column12: An AI tool taking small actions independently (e.g. drafting content without asking)
column13: An AI tool making decisions for you when you havenâ€™t given explicit approval
column14: An AI tool remembering past conversations and using them to guide new ones
column15: An AI tool suggesting actions you did not expect or ask for
column16: I feel uneasy when an AI tool responds inconsistently to the same question.
column17: Sudden changes in tone or behaviour from AI make me question its reliability.
column18: I prefer AI tools that behave predictably, even if they are less powerful.
column19: AI talking in a highly emotional or personal way
column20: AI using personal details to tailor responses
column21: AI giving strong opinions about sensitive topics
column22: AI becoming overly confident in its answers
column23: I sometimes overlook potential risks because AI tools make my tasks easier.
column24: The convenience of AI is worth accepting some level of uncertainty.
column25: An AI tool offering guidance during a stressful moment (e.g., conflict, crisis, decision pressure)
column26: An AI tool proactively warning you about potential risks in your behaviour
column27: An AI tool predicting your future choices based on past interactions
column28: I expect AI systems to become safer over time.
column29: I am more concerned about future AI than the AI we have today.
column30: I double-check AI information with other sources.
column31: I avoid certain questions or topics with AI because Iâ€™m unsure how it will respond.
column32: I reduce how much I use AI when it feels unpredictable or confusing.

column33: I answered based on ChatGPT/Gemini/etc use, but I would have answered differently when it comes to localAI (e.g. Llama or Qwen etc). In those cases I am more open with the AI and more likely feel less risk that it has my data and chat history. However the flip side is that local models are usually behind the open ones, so perhaps I trust local responses less when it comes to trust in quality of info.

column33: I'm wary of current generative AIs particularly LLMs, with issues such as hallucination and other unpredictable errors, and risks inherent in human interaction with chatbots etc. (see e.g. the "Eliza Effect" for a classic but still relevant example predating modern AI, but the risks now are more complex and extensive than that).  I'm confident that technology will continue improving, but I'm also concerned that some types of risks could actually expand, even with efforts to mitigate risks.  I'm torn between optimistic and pessimism about the future of AI influencing essentially all aspects of human life.  I'm also concerned about other unresolved AI-related issues such as growing resource and energy usage.
column38: Transparency, Accountability, I have a too strong an inclination to select more than 3 of the most important criteria here.  We need Accountable and Transparent and what I'd call Reliable AI, insofar as possible, and we also need to prioritize non-harm and human well-being and even environmental well-being, and we need robust Ethical Frameworks and Guardrails, etc. â€“ ALL of these and more are going to be very important indeed.

column33: I avoid talking about politics and other sensitive or controversial topics with AI because they are programmed to be politically correct instead of honest about such topics. They generally go with whatever is the establishment position or politically correct position, such as saying the covid vaccine is safe and effective and that it helped millions of people when it actually didn't help anyone and it's a bioweapon. Most of the time I can decide for myself whether AI is right or wrong. Sometimes I check with other sources.

column33: My main concern surrounding AI safety, is that I have observed both heavy religious and political bias. I fear it will be used as yet another propaganda tool and that people will walk blindly into it. AI could and should be pure and a tool for real advancement of the human race, but I fear this will not be the case. Greed and thirst for power will likely win.

column4: Information or research, Work tasks, Decision-making
column33: I think like most tools it will get better and less biased in the future but it's up to users to remain skeptical and not blindly accept results, just like most people wouldnt automatically just accept the first result on a Google search

column33: As it stands now, I'm quite comfortable using AI for the purposes I currently use it for. I find it very helpful to me. I do not use it for highly personal purposes.

column33: There needs to be laws regarding deepfakes in the AI community at the moment. Right now, there are no limitations on what  can and can't be generated within the law and it's all fun and games till it gets too realistic to tell apart from real life scenarios.
